awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Streak Camera System for Time-resolved Photoluminescence Spectroscopy
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Description:
Photoluminescence is light emission from a material after absorption of light in a different color with a shorter wavelength or a higher photon energy. The color of the emitted light provides important information about the material's electronic properties. A streak camera is a complex scientific instrument that measures the variation of the intensity of light pulses with respect to time with picosecond temporal resolution. This major research instrumentation (MRI) grant adds a streak camera to an existing photoluminescence measurement system. The combined instrument enables time-resolved photoluminescence measurements to study the dynamics of the electronic relaxation processes in materials such as semiconductors, protein receptors, and DNA. The new equipment strengthens training of the graduate and undergraduate students at Brooklyn College. The instrument is accessible to other institutions in the New York City area, and thus promotes broader collaboration and enhances research expertise. In addition, the educational benefit extends to local high school students who are involved in research projects at Brooklyn College.

Technical Description:
The acquisition of a streak camera extends the time-resolved measurement capability in the current photoluminescence system at Brooklyn College. The instrument supports a research project on wide bandgap semiconductors for solid state single photon emissions. It helps understanding the underlying optical and electronic properties and carrier dynamics in the emission processes, which is necessary for photonic device application of such materials. The addition of the streak camera also supports research on photodynamics of the cation-pi interaction and its role in protein function. It enables measurements of lifetimes in temporal resolution up to picoseconds with wavelengths ranging from the deep ultraviolet to the visible for continued progress in the spectroscopic characterization of cation-pi interactions. The extended temporal and optical range of the combined instrument is also applied to a study of the dynamics of biological macromolecules: G-quadruplexed DNA.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF funded project, MRI: Acquisition of a Streak Camera System for Time-resolved Photoluminescence Spectroscopy has been successfully completed by end of August 2024. With this fund, we were able to purchase a high-resolution streak camera to enhance the time-resolved capability in our existing deep ultra violet photoluminescence spectroscopy system. The newly purchased streak camera is from Hamamatsu, the world leader in the manufacture of sensitive optical devices. This streak camera can detect light signal very fast. It has time resolution up to 1 pico second. This camera has been successfully coupled to the monochromator of the photoluminescence spectroscopy by building an adaptor in the machine shop at Brooklyn College. The camera has also been tested. Upgrading the laser system is going on for the life-time measurements of the luminescence from wide bandgap semiconductor materials. Acquisition of the streak camera has added a big asset in the research facility at Brooklyn College which will be used for more than a decade for research projects of measuring life time of luminescence.

 

A PhD student and an undergraduate student have been trained on the operation of laser needed for the spectroscopy system. More students will have opportunity to learn such a sophisticated instrument and involve in scientific research projects. A new PhD student is going to join next semester for a new project using this system. This system will also be made available to other CUNY colleges.

 

During this project period, the PI gave an invited presentation on the related topic in the annual conference of Association of Nepalese Physicists in America (ANPA)-2023 and published a review paper, “Review article on "Al-rich AlGaN Alloys: Unique Materials for Deep UV LEDs" in the conference Journal of NPS 2024. DOI: http://doi.org/10.3126/jnphyssoc.v9i3.62454. Additionally, the PI and collaborator also published a second article, "Atomic-like UV emission generated in hexagonal boron nitride single crystals by thermal annealing" in the Journal of Luminescence volume 275, page 120756 in 2024, DOI: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jlumin.2024.120756. One more paper on the origin of atomic-like emission has been submitted and is under review now.

 

This project has also made impact on high school students. The PIs made presentations on the ‘High School Day’ organized by Chemistry department of Brooklyn College during the Fall semesters of 2023 and 2024. The PIs gave tours to about 150 students each year from 7-8 different high schools from New York city in the research laboratories to show how scientific research are done and gave demonstrations. Students were very excited to learn how electrons are involved in the generation of light and different technologies of generating light. Students were very impressed with those demonstrations and inspired to pursue college degree in science and engineering.
